caption.p: Relationships between elevation and predawn adaxial epidermal UV-A transmittances in Vaccinium reticulatum (native species) and Verbascum thapsus (non-native species) (A), and the relationship between midday summer clear sky erythemal UV-B irradiance (UV-B ERY) and predawn adaxial epidermal UV-A transmittance in V. thapsus (B). Data are means ± SE ( n = 10). Linear regression models in panel (A) were significant for V. thapsus ( P < 0.001; y = 11.13–0.0014 x) but not for V. reticulatum ( P = 0.87). The best-fit line relating epidermal UV-A transmittance to %UV-B ERY for V. thapsus in panel (B) is a third-order polynomial model [ y = 32.2 – 0.28 x + 0.022( x – 90.2) 2 – 0.0007( x – 90.2) 3], which is significant at P = 0.003. UV-B ERY data are expressed relative to the value at the highest sampling elevation on Mauna Kea as per data from Nullet and Juvik (1997).
